name: Research Methods in Cognitive Psychology

prereqs.text: ((85-211 [] at least D) or (85-213 [] at least D) or (85-110 [] at least D)) and ((85-309 [] at least D) or (36-309 [] at least D)) and ((85-300 [] at least D) or (85-320 [] at least D) or (85-340 [] at least D) or (85-311 [] at least D) or (85-314 [] at least D))

long_desc: This is a course in which students develop the research skills associated with cognitive psychology and cognitive science. Students learn how to design and conduct experiments, and analyze and interpret the data they collect. The course covers a variety of experimental designs, e.g., factorial, Latin Squares. Analyses of response times, qualitative data, and signal detection are also covered. Cognitive modeling will also be discussed. Topics include mental imagery, memory, and perception. The class format consists of lectures, discussions and student presentations.

custom_fields.goals: The broad aim of this course is to teach students the skills and concepts necessary to create, report, and evaluate scientific knowledge about human cognition. In addition to class lectures and discussions, students will participate in projects designed to introduce them to representative experiments in the field. Students will design and conduct a pilot research project, gain an understanding of research methodology, and enhance their ability to analyze and communicate research findings. If successful, this course will improve a students ability to1. recognize and apply basic principles of scientific research, measurement, and experimental design2. consider ethical issues associated with research 3. use library and other resources to find out what is known about a research topic4. design and conduct a research project5. communicate research findings effectively, both orally and in writing6. evaluate others research critically and constructively.
custom_fields.key_topics:
Research Methods in Cognitive Psychology.
Experimental Design.
Hypothesis testing.
Finding & Relating Relevant Research Literature within a topic.
Research Ethics.
Data Analysis.
Data Presentation and Communication.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge:
Students should have a firm grasp of the core theories and findings in the field of Cognitive Psychology.
Students should know how to read and understand a research article in Cognitive Psychology.
Students must know how to use SPSS and Excel to conduct data analyses and must understand which statistical tests are appropriate to use.
Although not required, it helps to have taken some type of computer programming course because creating cognitive experiments requires learning to use a program called Eprime. No background in Eprime is necessary, but a general familiarity with computer programming is useful.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will take quizzes related to the textbook and will do in-class activities and discussion for credit. Students will write up two research projects during this course. For the second project, students will need to create an original experiment from start to finish, including: experimental design, creating stimuli, creating a program to present the stimuli, and analyzing data. For each project, students will produce a paper in APA format that will be graded. In addition, for the final project, there will be a poster session presenting the research to the Psychology department. Posters will be assessed on the clarity of their content, adherence to APA format, and students' ability to answer questions about the research.
custom_fields.relevance: This course fulfills a requirement for most Psychology-affiliated majors. It has central relevance to developing the ability to critically evaluate any empirical evidence discussed in scientific classes. It provides useful skills and experience to anyone who wants to work in a research lab.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Students purchase a textbook: Morling, Beth. Reseach Methods in Psychology: Evaluating a World of Information. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. This textbook also has a blog: http://wwnorton.com/college/psych/research-methods-in-psychology/blog.aspx There are websites with information about how to use the Eprime program to run experiments at this URL: https://step.talkbank.org/ The CMU library provides access to original research articles that students will read when searching for articles related to their research project.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students will work on a group project and usually need to arrange mutually convenient times meet with their group outside of class in order to complete the project. During approximately two weeks during the semester, the students may need to participate in data collection activities outside of class time. There is a required poster session in the last week of class that meets outside of class time; that date and time are announced at the start of the semester.
